On Wed, 2 Jun 2004 17:08:50 +0100 (BST), Kennon Lynn Ballou
<msc92klb@...> wrote:
> 
> Well, I graduated from UT/austin and am now a master's student here at the
> University of Birmingham (UK), studying Natural Computation.
> 
> It really sounds _exactly_ like what you are looking for - very
> interdisciplinary. There is alot of really good research going on at this
> school, and since about 2/3rds of the course is research based there are
> alot of good opportunities for advisors.
> 
> The course website is here:
> http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/study/postgraduate-taught/msc-nc/

Thanks for the link.  It does sound like what I'm looking for...though
I was hoping to find a PhD program to enter directly, though that may
not be realistic.  It's nice that the program is compacted into a
year, though I'd guess it's pretty intensive.

It sounds a bit like the program at the Univ. of Sussex, which I did
run across in my search:

http://www.sussex.ac.uk/informatics/1-3-2-2-7-1-2.html

Have you (or anyone) heard anything about that program?

> Additionally, it only takes 1 year for a master's degree over here - which
> is a good thing because it does tend to be rather expensive in the UK. The
> course was designed to identify good researchers, with a strong push to
> continue on with a PhD. However, there are far fewer funding options for
> americans over here, which is why I'm most likely not going to be able to
> continue on here after this year.

That's too bad.  That does sound like it might be a significant issue
for me.  Do they not offer research assistantships, or work programs,
or something similar?

> They also don't require an application fee nor do they look at your GRE
> scores (which was a good thing for me :)

No application fee is nice.  Though I'd probably prefer they looked at
my GRE scores, rather than my undergrad grades. :)

> Feel free to email me privately or on the list if you have any more
> specific questions.

So are you finishing up your degree program this summer?  Are you
working on a thesis right now?

Thanks for the info.

Derek
